> The CLI will still display stale values for "Host Lane Count" and "Media Lane Count" after setting the application. Are you planning to address this as well?

Yes, I have now also update "Host Lane Count" and "Media Lane Count".

> Wondering if we should create a wrapper to the below function and update the TRANSCEIVER_INFO table accordingly? https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-platform-daemons/blob/81048cd1fb63da9fdca567aa863c7d1d43156ed3/sonic-xcvrd/xcvrd/xcvrd.py#L1587C36-L1587C51

I think it would be better not to update TRANSCEIVER_INFO table until data path is activated.

> @MichaelWangSmci can you also take care of the case where user executes 'config interface shutdown' in which case module datapaths remain deactivated?

After 'config interface shutdown' module datapaths state are 'DataPathInitialized' because Tx are disabled.
In this case, the active control set are not updated, right?

> > @MichaelWangSmci can you also take care of the case where user executes 'config interface shutdown' in which case module datapaths remain deactivated?
> 
> After 'config interface shutdown' module datapaths state are 'DataPathInitialized' because Tx are disabled. In this case, the active control set are not updated, right?

@MichaelWangSmci yes not updated, but won't it confuse the user ? if the datapath is no

> > @MichaelWangSmci can you also take care of the case where user executes 'config interface shutdown' in which case module datapaths remain deactivated?
> 
> After 'config interface shutdown' module datapaths state are 'DataPathInitialized' because Tx are disabled. In this case, the active control set are not updated, right?

@MichaelWangSmci right.

> @yxieca @StormLiangMS please help cherry pick this accordingly.

ADO - 21982389

> could you add the DPB (Dynamic Port Breakout) CLI being validated here? is it validating DPB CLI on 100G or 400G optical module (transceiver)?
> 
> Also, please add the UT logs to the PR

I added UT logs. I validated it via DPB CLI for both 100G and 400G. But I don't think DPB is a major concern here. The problem is that if we removing/adding logic port, there would be a race condition in xcvrd. I used a private script to delete/add logic port to CONFIG DB in a while loop. The issue can be reproduced without my fix, and it is gone with my fix.
Hi @prgeor , checker passed. Could you please review and sign-off?

>> I validated it via DPB CLI for both 100G and 400G.

sonic 400G optics model is based on CMIS FSM (state machine) driven by xcvrd.
port breakout with CMIS enabled is under works and yet not there.
So, could you clarify if you did 400G optical module DPB validation with xcvrd but without CMIS in play?

If you are talking about CMIS manager, Nvidia platform does not use it. CMIS manager is disabled on Nvidia platform. Why do you think DPB and CMIS manager is related this PR? It is all about race condition while removing and adding logical port.

> If you are talking about CMIS manager, Nvidia platform does not use it. CMIS manager is disabled on Nvidia platform. Why do you think DPB and CMIS manager is related this PR? It is all about race condition while removing and adding logical port.

Thanks for the update.
Reason I asked: In its git issue, you mentioned "steps to reproduce the issue"
Use dynamic port breakout CLI to split port, there is a small chance to hit this issue.

So, looking for following UT test case (steps). could you attach the following data to this PR?
1.  snippet of platform.json and hwsku.json for the interface where DPB CLI was issued
2. config DB snippet for the interface (before issuing DPB CLI)
3. DPB CLI issued
4. config DB snippet for this interface (after issuing DPB CLI)
5. syslog etc. traces (esp. syncd) showing removal (of existing ports) and creation of new logical/sub-ports
6. syslog etc. traces for xcvrd flow for this scenario
@shyam77git please review

> > If you are talking about CMIS manager, Nvidia platform does not use it. CMIS manager is disabled on Nvidia platform. Why do you think DPB and CMIS manager is related this PR? It is all about race condition while removing and adding logical port.
> 
> Thanks for the update. Reason I asked: In its git issue, you mentioned "steps to reproduce the issue" Use dynamic port breakout CLI to split port, there is a small chance to hit this issue.
> 
> So, looking for following UT test case (steps). could you attach the following data to this PR?
> 
> 1. snippet of platform.json and hwsku.json for the interface where DPB CLI was issued
> 2. config DB snippet for the interface (before issuing DPB CLI)
> 3. DPB CLI issued
> 4. config DB snippet for this interface (after issuing DPB CLI)
> 5. syslog etc. traces (esp. syncd) showing removal (of existing ports) and creation of new logical/sub-ports
> 6. syslog etc. traces for xcvrd flow for this scenario

Hi @shyam77git, 

1. The issue is not related to platform.json or hwsku.json. It is just related to adding/removing logical port. DPB CLI will remove the existing logic port and create new ones no matter what platform.json/hwsku.json is. You can use `config interface breakout <interface> <mode>` on ANY interface with ANY valid mode to reproduce the issue, but you may need to run it in a while loop for few hours to hit the race condition.
2. I found the root cause not by analyzing the syslog. Actually, there is no clue in the syslog. I found the issue by reading the code. So, I am not sure that providing the trace is helpful to understand the issue. 

Example, say we are going to break Ethernet0 to (Ethernet0 and Ethernet2)  :
1. It removes Ethernet0 first, `TRANSCEIVER_STATUS|Ethernet0` will be removed from TRANSCEIVER_STATUS table
2. It adds Ethernet0 back to CONFIG_DB, both SfpStateUpdateTask and DomInfoUpdateTask notice the new logic port.  SfpStateUpdateTask and DomInfoUpdateTask run in two different thread. So, there could be 2 possible cases:
  a. SfpStateUpdateTask get port add event first. No issue for this flow.
  b. DomInfoUpdateTask get port add event first. This flow causes issue. See below.

Let discuss case b:
1. DomInfoUpdateTask get port add event first. It calls update_port_transceiver_status_table_hw which will populate a few data to `TRANSCEIVER_STATUS|Ethernet0`, but it does not populate "status" field.
2. Then, SfpStateUpdateTask gets new port add event. It calls on_port_config_change -> on_add_logical_port and hit the line:
```
        logical_port_event_dict[port_change_event.port_name] = dict(sfp_status)['status']   <===== crash because 'status' is not a valid key in dict(sfp_status)
```

`TRANSCEIVER_STATUS|Ethernet0` has no 'status' field yet, so the above line get an KeyError and crashes. 

I hope this is clear now.
Hi @prgeor @shyam77git , could you please review and sign-off?

how the 4x10 or 4x25 breakout is taken cared for 100G/40G module ?

> how the 4x10 or 4x25 breakout is taken cared for 100G/40G module ?

The API get_cmis_application_desired will return the application ID by matching the speed and number of active host lanes from CONFIG_DB. This application ID will then be used by get_cmis_host_lanes function to find the appropriate active host lanes.

> I get_cmis_application_desired will return the application ID by matching the speed and number of active host lanes from CONFIG_DB. This application ID will then be used by get_cmis_host_lanes function to find the appropriate active host lanes.

get_cmis_host_lanes() is not supposed to be invoked for non-CMIS module isn't it ? 
the question is for breakout 4x25G and 4x10G on non-cmis (100G/40G modules)

> hannel > host_lane_



> > I get_cmis_application_desired will return the application ID by matching the speed and number of active host lanes from CONFIG_DB. This application ID will then be used by get_cmis_host_lanes function to find the appropriate active host lanes.
> 
> get_cmis_host_lanes() is not supposed to be invoked for non-CMIS module isn't it ? the question is for breakout 4x25G and 4x10G on non-cmis (100G/40G modules)

Yes,  get_cmis_host_lanes() will not be invoked for non-CMIS module.
Since 4x25G and 4x10G are non-CMIS modules, datapath initialization from xcvrd is not required and hence, the current changes are not needed for such modules.
The expectation is that existing bring-up sequence outside of xcvrd should take care of initial reset for such modules and then, it should work as is without the intervention of xcvrd.

> > hannel > host_lane_
> 
> > > I get_cmis_application_desired will return the application ID by matching the speed and number of active host lanes from CONFIG_DB. This application ID will then be used by get_cmis_host_lanes function to find the appropriate active host lanes.
> > 
> > 
> > get_cmis_host_lanes() is not supposed to be invoked for non-CMIS module isn't it ? the question is for breakout 4x25G and 4x10G on non-cmis (100G/40G modules)
> 
> Yes, get_cmis_host_lanes() will not be invoked for non-CMIS module. Since 4x25G and 4x10G are non-CMIS modules, datapath initialization from xcvrd is not required and hence, the current changes are not needed for such modules. The expectation is that existing bring-up sequence outside of xcvrd should take care of initial reset for such modules and then, it should work as is without the intervention of xcvrd.

@mihirpat1 , @prgeor 
For non-CMIS compliant modules (i.e. SFF* spec based ones), one cannot expect them to work seamlessly. 
Beside xcvrd, following areas to be checked from code-flow and validation standpoint:
- syncd vertical (syncd-> SAI-> SDK) w.r.t handling the port brea-out
- use case: shut, no-shut on a particular channel (broken-down/logical port) of an interface
- though xcvrd vertical seems to have no role (per above-mentioned explanation), still its part of end-to-end validation to ensure no open item/issue
I'd suggest to file a separate git issue for this

@shyam77git - I have now added test cases 9 - 12 to address the same.
@mihirpat1 can we test if the link is UP and Xcvrd crashes or PMON restarts, the link does not flap?

In the Notes, "Once the **port_config.ini** file has a new column for channel, the CONFIG_DB will be updated with the corresponding channel values (requires minigraph reload though)."

I am a bit of concern that to extend "port_config.ini" for this purpose, AFAIK,  "platform.json" was introduced for the dynamic port breakout, I think we should consider extending it instead of "port_config.ini".
by the way, have you already had a PR for this part?

> In the Notes, "Once the **port_config.ini** file has a new column for channel, the CONFIG_DB will be updated with the corresponding channel values (requires minigraph reload though)."
> 
> I am a bit of concern that to extend "port_config.ini" for this purpose, AFAIK, "platform.json" was introduced for the dynamic port breakout, I think we should consider extending it instead of "port_config.ini". by the way, have you already had a PR for this part?

@keboliu  we can remove the reference to port_config.ini as its not relevant to this Xcvrd changes. Please see my email.

As I commented in PR, https://github.com/sonic-net/SONiC/pull/1290

Using 'channel' to refer to a 'sub-port' is misleading. XCVRD is mainly dealing with optical cables. In the optical cables context, 'channel' is a concept which already widely used and has a clear definition, we even have SONiC platform APIs defined to handle optical cable 'channels'. I suggest to use use another name to avoid confusion.

Another point is that not sure the 'channel' number should be provided explicitly from some configuration, can it be deduced by some logic? It's shouldn't be too complicated.

I believe that instead of explicitly giving the subport/channel info in port_config.ini it should be derived from the existing information in port_config.ini (i.e.) we have defined the rules for "name" , "alias" and "index".  Same convention should be following in DPB as well. If there is difference in DPB with the above rules, it should be addressed in the DPB document to match it.  If we diverge here then we will have to do the same additional information in DPB as well.

> I believe that instead of explicitly giving the subport/channel info in port_config.ini it should be derived from the existing information in port_config.ini (i.e.) we have defined the rules for "name" , "alias" and "index". Same convention should be following in DPB as well. If there is difference in DPB with the above rules, it should be addressed in the DPB document to match it. If we diverge here then we will have to do the same additional information in DPB as well.

As discussed, having a logic in xcvrd to calculate subport info introduces dependencies on neighboring subports belonging to the same physical group. This also relies on the fact that redis-db will always populate info for all subports in a physical port group before xcvrd actually starts using info for a subport.
In addition to this, the current physical to logical port list is not in sorted order and will need to be sorted in appropriate order before using it.

@yxieca please help cherry pick to 202205
@StormLiangMS please help cherry pick to 202211
Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

@rlhui @abdosi  The reply has been made last week.  Somehow it has been moved to the section before this comment. 
 --  Before this PR, these "FABRIC_ASIC" entries will be removed if stop chassisd or PMON (which trigger the de_init). The entries will be recreated when chassisd or PMON is restarted. Function module_updater.module_db_update() will recreate them. We have manaully test it. But, after this PR, these fabric entries will not be removed when PMON/chassis is stopped.

> > Please address the comment
> 
> @prem-nokia reminder on this

This is already addressed by @mlok-nokia last week. Thanks

@prem-nokia Instead of making this workaround the problem, can we make the test more intelligent? It doesn't look correct to NOT delete the DB entries owned/created by PMON to be NOT deleted once PMON is dead. In the test we can get the list of asics before PMON  is stopped and use that list after PMON is stopped.?

> @prem-nokia Instead of making this workaround the problem, can we make the test more intelligent? It doesn't look correct to NOT delete the DB entries owned/created by PMON to be NOT deleted once PMON is dead. In the test we can get the list of asics before PMON is stopped and use that list after PMON is stopped.?

@arlakshm @prgeor @anamehra @rlhui  Please help to decide what we should do here.  Based on the feature, these entries should not be removed since they are used to start the swss/syncd on the Supervisor card.

> @prem-nokia Instead of making this workaround the problem, can we make the test more intelligent? It doesn't look correct to NOT delete the DB entries owned/created by PMON to be NOT deleted once PMON is dead. In the test we can get the list of asics before PMON is stopped and use that list after PMON is stopped.?

@prgeor , the issue is not limited to the test case. It's more of a design issue. How do we want to handle a situation where pmon goes down due to some error and later syncd/swss restarts?

> > @prem-nokia Instead of making this workaround the problem, can we make the test more intelligent? It doesn't look correct to NOT delete the DB entries owned/created by PMON to be NOT deleted once PMON is dead. In the test we can get the list of asics before PMON is stopped and use that list after PMON is stopped.?
> 
> @prgeor , the issue is not limited to the test case. It's more of a design issue. How do we want to handle a situation where pmon goes down due to some error and later syncd/swss restarts?

@prem-nokia @anamehra PMON going down is highly unlikely event which could happen with swss/syncd docker as well.  I think the issue is mainly to do with the design where PMON is now critical docker

> > > @prem-nokia Instead of making this workaround the problem, can we make the test more intelligent? It doesn't look correct to NOT delete the DB entries owned/created by PMON to be NOT deleted once PMON is dead. In the test we can get the list of asics before PMON is stopped and use that list after PMON is stopped.?
> > 
> > 
> > @prgeor , the issue is not limited to the test case. It's more of a design issue. How do we want to handle a situation where pmon goes down due to some error and later syncd/swss restarts?
> 
> @prem-nokia @anamehra PMON going down is highly unlikely event which could happen with swss/syncd docker as well. I think the issue is mainly to do with the design where PMON is now critical docker

Yes, @prgeor , I agree with that. As we discussed in the meeting, this PR is good to have fix to the time being to handle double failure scenarios. We should track the design improvements to handle the possible PMON failure as a critical issue.

reviews.body:
If I understand it correctly, the graceful restart notification is implemented by looping below?
fetch ToR side from request queue -> send request to server -> process response -> sleep if there is a restart period -> put ToR in request queue -> ...
Discussed offline. @prgeor can you also review this PR?

@jaganbal-a @shyam77git please review

> @mihirpat1 can you check the behavior if you kill the threads with `kill -9`

It seems we won't be able to kill threads using `kill -9` since `kill` requires process ID as a parameter. I have attached UT for killing xcvrd process though.
What if "CmisManagerTask " is disabled with intention? On the Mellanox platforms "CmisManagerTask" is disabled by setting the "skip_xcvrd_cmis_mgr" to "true".

> What if "CmisManagerTask " is disabled with intention? On the Mellanox platforms "CmisManagerTask" is disabled by setting the "skip_xcvrd_cmis_mgr" to "true".

If "CmisManagerTask" is disabled with intention, we will not spawn thread for it. Also, I have attached the UT for it (`#8` in [xcvrd_thread_support.txt](https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-platform-daemons/files/10313858/xcvrd_thread_support.txt))
